Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Philosophy of Technology
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: If SPEP began to challenge sixties professional philosophy externally, internally positivism was also being challenged. Its dominant form was undergoing a different set of challenges, which related to the notion of science itself. This was the era of the positivist/antipositivist controversies (there was not yet what could be called a parallel or related philosophy of technology subdiscipline). For those of you too young to remember, or not even yet born, it should be noted that for many positivists and some analysts, philosophy of science was all that was needed for philosophy. Philosophy of science equaled philosophy. Metaphysics, aesthetics, and whole areas of traditional philosophy were to be abandoned or regarded as “nonsense.” This version of philosophy-science, however, was met by Thomas Kuhn's 1962 The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, to become the twentieth-century's most cited book, along with his kin, Karl Popper, Imre Lakatos, and Paul Feyerabend, who collectively were depicting a very different science, discontinuous, historical, using technologies (instruments), no longer simply a logo-linguistic, propositional theory machine.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0321 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0321.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Ethics and Religion in Continental Philosophy
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: In my own opinion the most interesting expression of the religious turn in Continental philosophy is found in Derrida because Derrida is by anyone's standards a secular thinker and even, by the standards of the local pastor or rabbi, an atheist. So it came as a shock to read about Derrida's “religion” in his famous “Circumfession” (1989), which is a deconstructive riff on Augustine's Confessionsin which Derrida restages the scene of theConfessions. We come upon a scene in which the speaker (Augustine/Jackie), an emigrant from North Africa to the Big Apple (Rome/Paris), has his back to us and is praying to someone (te, God/tu), while his mother (Monica/Georgette) lies dying on the northern shore of the Mediterranean (Ostia/Nice). Derrida tells us that he has been praying all his life and that no one, not even his mother, has understood this, which has led to a misunderstanding of his work. But to whom is Derrida praying, and how could he be praying at all? Does he not “rightly pass for an atheist”?20 There is a more obscure sense of religion “without religion” in Derrida, and a prayer to a God not only unknown but nonexistent that nonetheless constitutes a genuine prayer. If, as Jean-Louis Chrétien says, himself one of the new religious phenomenologists,21 prayeris a “wounded word,” what word is more wounded than a word from one who does not know to whom he is praying (a lost letter, destination unknown), or if anyone is there to hear his prayers, or if he is praying at all, who has to pray to be able to pray at all, for something, he knows not what, something “coming,” the coming or incoming (invention) of something unforeseeable? Derrida's atheism is crucially important to his religion because it allows him to isolate the very structure of prayer, and hence of the religious posture, with or without what we in the great monotheisms call “God,” thereby putting into questi~
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0333 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0333.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Is a Hermeneutic Phenomenology Wide Enough? A Ricoeurian Reply to Janicaud's
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.28.3.issue-3
Date: 7 1, 2014
Author(s): Davidson Scott
Abstract: Hermeneutics, moreover, challenges the central role that Husserl ascribes to intuition, especially in his early works. The call to return to the things themselves is heeded by a return to what is given in intuition. But, as Ricoeur puts it, “the Husserlian demand for the return to intuition is countered by the necessity for all understanding to be mediated by an interpretation.” In support of this claim, Ricoeur draws inspiration from Heidegger's conception of the as-structure of being, which maintains that being is always revealed in a partial manner, as this or as that.13 This as-structure suggests that nothing is ever directly or fully given, and for this reason, what is given always calls for a process of interpretation enabling it to be seen as this or that. If it is the case that all givenness is perspectival and partial, Ricoeur contends that phenomenology “cannot constitute itself without a14 hermeneutical presupposition. The hermeneutical condition of phenomenology is linked to the role ofAuslegungin the fulfillment of its philosophical project.” 15
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.28.3.0315 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.28.3.0315.xml

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: Translator's notes
Publisher: Johns Hopkins University Press
Issue: philrhet.44.2.issue-1
Date: 6 1, 1956
Abstract: In this work, I argue that creative metaphors are formed when some persistent problem, caused by an inadequacy in preexisting knowledge, descends into the collective unconscious, is reconfigured unconsciously in novel ways, and then reemerges back into consciousness where the impasse is resolved by the metaphorical expression of new knowledge. To develop this position, I (1) review and critique some well-known language-based studies of metaphor, (2) summarize psychoanalytic and depth psychological approaches to the psyche as one way to overcome the shortcomings of the language-based scholarship, (3) relate C. G. Jung's account of the psyche and his related notion of synchronicity to creative metaphors, (4) graft a quantum physics approach to material reality back onto Jung's work as a provisional structure of the collective unconscious, and finally, (5) offer some suggestions about how creative metaphors might work psychologically.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.44.2.0101 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.44.2.0101.xml

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: Recovering Hyperbole:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: philrhet.45.4.issue-4
Date: 12 1, 2012
Abstract: Derrida states that hyperbole is “the uneconomic expenditure,” which both can and cannot exceed economy. His statement has the structure of error without being an error. He speaks the language of extremity and of exceeding economy in order to emphasize the repetitive necessity of making the attempt to “throw beyond.” Through hyperbolic errancy, the repetition of the attempt-to-say-the-demonic-hyperbole, the signifier exceeds the signified that is already in excess. The attempt will never be completed but is always necessary. Thus, Derrida engages in a hyperbolic mode of thought regarding hyperbole itself in order to reveal that the radical attempt to throw beyond the economy of writing is an impossible possibility that must always be attempted but will never arrive.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.45.4.0406 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.45.4.0406.xml

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: “Reading the Past against the Grain: The Shape of Memory Studies.”
Publisher: University of Chicago Press
Issue: philrhet.46.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 1998
Abstract: Second, how do we account for the fact that the processes of public memory are both created by individual choices and nurtured in collective contexts? Many scholars have productively addressed this question by unpacking specific examples in which individuals or groups vie to control public memories. The critical framework I recommend offers a more systematic approach to this issue. To view representations of the past through the nested lenses of rhetoric, public memory, and the agential spiral is to focus on how human beings—individually and in groups—forge connections with people of other times through the medium of public agency. The agential spiral, derived from my reading of Ricoeur's “threefold mimesis,” aims to pinpoint three moments in the construction of narratives in which human action is represented and reinterpreted within a temporal structure. As a critical framework, the agential spiral helps us to view the creation of public memories at three key moments and to see the process as a coiling whole. Using this tool, we can better understand why certain memories persist in certain societies and how those memories powerfully connect people across time as well as space.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.46.2.0182 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.46.2.0182.xml

Journal Title: Shaw
Article Title: Bernard Shaw and Paul Ricoeur
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: shaw.34.1.issue-1
Date: 10 1, 2014
Author(s): Einsohn Howard Ira
Abstract: Ultimately, faith is a condition of possibility—a necessary component—for an engaged and efficacious hope. Put differently, faith is primary and hope is secondary. This is true in two senses, neither of which diminishes the significance of hope in human affairs. First, faith undergirds hope in the same way that a solid foundation supports a subsequent structure. The substratum comes first, then the library or theater. Without a firm base, hope atrophies and may even collapse entirely when the harsh winds of life reach gale force velocity—just as poorly designed buildings come tumbling down during category 1 hurricanes. Second, faith is the core of the two major comprehensive belief systems that have guided Homo sapiens' growth and development through the ages: religion and science. Respectively, one grounds faith in a transcendent or supernatural agency that guarantees order, meaning, and purpose in the cosmos; and the second grounds faith in the power of the human mind to plumb the mysteries of the universe accurately on its own through observation, measurement, and verifiable experimentation. Though often at odds with each other, these tussling worldviews have at least one attribute in common. They each engender and nourish hope, much as the sun emits radiant energy. In this schema, hope is neutral with respect to religion and science. It can spring full-blown from either source and, in a manner of speaking, does not burden itself with determining what precisely presides over the earth and sky. It simply hungers fervently after a better tomorrow, delegating the underwriting of its activities to faith. All of this is germane to our efforts here because Shaw and Ricoeur were not only apostles of hope. They were also men of devout religious faith. They possessed a deep and lasting reverence for what they took to be the numinous, in all of its manifestations.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/shaw.34.1.0133 journal-article-10.5325_shaw.34.1.0133.xml

Journal Title: Style
Article Title: “Introduction.”
Publisher: Norton
Issue: style.34.issue-2
Date: January 16, 1972
Author(s): Matz Jesse
Abstract: Mauriceis a novel that waits for the future (for completion, publication, and audience) but also looks nostagically to the past. This strange temporal location reflects a temporality basic to Forster's narrative structures and sexual identity: like philosophers who presently ascribe to the “tenseless theory of time,” Forster dispels identity among a tenseless order of moments, in a narrative structure that seeks likewise to trade “becoming” for a better order. InMaurice, such tactics as iterative seriality, overdetermined prolepsis, nonephiphany, and other modes of “detensing” give form to a version of homosexuality that would escape “identity,” with unusual implications for moderist temporality and narratological criticism. Forster's modernist time is eccentric for its interest in logical order; and the narratological criticism which would attend to his “tenseless” homosexual form must remember that it is often the combination of subversion and order that encourages the best narratological advances.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/style.34.2.188 journal-article-10.5325_style.34.2.188.xml

Journal Title: Style
Article Title: “The Liberation of Mourning in Elizabeth Bowen's
Publisher: UP of Virginia
Issue: style.36.issue-1
Date: 3 1, 1993
Author(s): Kelly Marian
Abstract: Elizabeth Bowen subjects both her characters and her readers to the dynamics of nostalgia in two of her novels. The House in ParisandThe Little Girlsare unique in Bowen'soeuvrein their use of “structural nostalgia”—a tripartite structure containing a section that takes place in the past put between two sections that take place in the present. Though this structure suggests that readers may simply engage in a nostalgic return along with the characters, Bowen uses it instead to force both her characters and her readers into a conscious examination of both the pleasures and the problems created by nostalgia.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/style.36.1.1 journal-article-10.5325_style.36.1.1.xml

Journal Title: Style
Article Title: “Purgatory Unpurged: Time, Space and Language in ‘Lessness.’”
Publisher: Cambridge UP
Issue: style.36.issue-1
Date: February 25, 1984
Author(s): Alber Jan
Abstract: In Towards a ‘Natural’ Narratology(1996), Monika Fludernik reconstitutes narrativity on the basis of experientiality, i.e., humanity's embodiedness in the world, and claims that incomprehensible texts can be made more readable if one attempts to narrativize them. Since Samuel Beckett's short prose work “Lessness” is one of the most enigmatic texts of the twentieth century, it serves as an ideal test case for this new narratological paradigm. “Lessness” does indeed lose its initial strangeness if one reads this piece as narrative. Moreover, although a “natural” narratological analysis paves the way for a new interpretation of “Lessness,” the new paradigm provides only a partially satisfying analysis of it. To make the text fit into the new consciousness-oriented paradigm, Fludernik's quasi-universal naturalizing mode has to ignore certain aspects such as the mechanical structure of “Lessness.” Beckett's later prose work challenges narrativization and the “natural” narratological project. A reading of “Lessness” should be liberated from the confines of experientiality and instead concentrate on the role of chance and chaos. Beckett's text must be located in a counterworld, a limbo between signifier and signified. One should allow this limbo world to seep into the “real world” and not attempt to explain this different counterworld by means of “real-world” knowledge.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/style.36.1.54 journal-article-10.5325_style.36.1.54.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Rhetorical Function of Utopia:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.23.1.issue-1
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: What is left unsaid in this article about the relationship between utopia and rhetoric could certainly fill the pages of many books. The range is especially rich when we turn to contemporary rhetorical theorists who specifically address society as a value to be combined with a remembered or imagined better place, as in Nedra Reynolds's Geographies of Writingor bell hooks'sBelonging: A Culture of Place. Just as constitutive rhetoric (that is, cumulative discourse that contributes to building the structure of human society) has been important in the works of theorists often cited by utopists as crucial to their work, so the utopian impulse continues to be inherent in the way rhetoricians see their subject. To persuade verbally or visually, we must have our own idea of what is socially better, and we must also be able to imagine what our audience believes to be better. The function of utopia, then, may be less philosophical and ideological at its root than it is linguistic in a pragmatic sense. As Kenneth Burke has written of human beings, we are “the symbol-making, symbol-using, symbol-misusing animal … rotten with perfection.”38 39
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.1.0113 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.1.0113.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Meta-Utopian Metatext:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.23.2.issue-2
Date: 10 1, 2012
Abstract: At the 1934 Congress of Soviet Writers, Karl Radek famously condemned Joyce's anally retentive bourgeois tendencies by comparing Ulysseswith “the component parts of a heap of dung.” It is certainly difficult to see bourgeois-suburban Joyce-Bloom as the epitome of the Modernist-Utopian tradition advanced by Jameson.71 Ulyssesis a novel of immense and endless structuration, but one that resists structure itself, which resists the closure and determinism of epic or stereotypically Utopian mythologization. Joyce's work would most obviously take place in the comic-ironic—rather than the mythic—stages of Northrop Frye's generic cycle. As Jameson himself suggests, “The incomparable greatness of [Ulysses] comes from itsincompleteuse of myth: Joyce lets us see that the ‘myth’ is nothing but an organizational device, and his subject is not some fictive unity of experience which the myth is supposed to guarantee, but rather that fragmentation of life in the modern world.” So much, then, for artificial or organic unities: so much, then, for a Joycean Utopia.72
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.2.0472 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.2.0472.xml
